questions: Do you want the license to allow modifications to your software?
Do you want to allow the licensed software and derivatives to be used for commercial purposes?
Do you want to allow your software to be used in proprietary (closed-source) applications?
Do you want to allow sublicensing of your software, e.g. addition of a different license?
Do you want modifications to your software to be released under the same license (when distributing the licensed software)?
Do you want to specify that any modifications made to your software must be indicated when redistributed?
Do you want to allow users that interact with the licensed software via a network to receive a copy of the source code?
Are you concerned about copyright, patents, or trademarks in your work?
Do you want the original copyright to be retained?
Do you want to give users the right to practice patent claims of contributors to the code?
Do you want to allow the use of trademarks in your work?
question_explanations: This question asks if you agree with others changing your code. Depending on your preference, you can allow full modifications, specific types of changes, or none at all.
This question asks if others can use your software or modified versions (derivatives) to make profit. Allowing this may require charging a fee or offering specific terms.
This question asks if programs combining your software can be kept closed-source (code hidden), or if the combined code must be openly shared.
If you allow sublicensing, it means that others who get a license from you can grant different licenses than the one you used to others (sublicense).
This question affects how modifications to your software are shared. You can require the same license you are using or allow different licenses.
This question asks if you want users to mention changes they performed on your software when sharing your software or derivatives.

This question applies to software accessed over a network (such as web applications). You can decide if the software will remain open source, even when users are interacting with the software over a network.
This asks if you want legal protection for your software's code, features, or name. Copyright covers the code, patents protect specific functionalities, and trademarks safeguard unique names/logos.
Even if you share your software, you can retain copyright unless stated otherwise. This allows you to claim ownership and potentially seek legal action if your rights are violated.
If others contribute code to your project, you can decide if they retain patent rights related to their additions.
This question asks if others can use your unique names or logos within their applications.
